thread.title: Lots of fireworks at Baylor- Tech ... here are a few numbers worth noting
thread.title_full: Lots of fireworks at Baylor-Texas Tech ... here are a few numbers worth noting | Dallas Morning News

author: Tommy Cummings
title: Lots of fireworks at Baylor- Tech ... here are a few numbers worth noting
text:
LIVE BOX SCORE
At midweek, 90.5 points was the over/under for the Baylor-Texas Tech football game Saturday at AT&T Stadium in Arlington.
By halftime, that total appeared to be adorbs.
Baylor and Texas Tech rolled up 70 points and 820 yards between them. They each ran 44 plays.
Baylor led 49-21 at the break. The Bears looked to be on a 100-point pace after the first quarter, leading 28-14.
Baylor and Texas Tech are on pace for approximately 2,723 points.
— ESPNU (@ESPNU) October 3, 2015 Going into the game, the two teams averaged 117.8 points between them.
Tech quarterback Pat Mahomes had put up 255 yards passing. Baylor's Seth Russell had 251 yards on 11 completions.
Baylor running back Shock Linwood had 169 yards on 12 carries, including a 79-yard run that opened the game with 65 seconds gone. In the fourth quarter, his total had grown to 214 yards, which was a career high and fourth-most in school history. He finished with 221 yards.
In addition, Jay Lee's 87-yard reception in the second quarter was Baylor's sixth-longest in school history. It was the longest pass in AT&T Stadium history.
Baylor's 28 first-quarter points are the most scored by an FBS team in any quarter at AT&T Stadium. The Bears' 49 first-half points are the most scored in any half at AT&T.
Baylor's nine touchdowns are tied for most in a college game at AT&T. Baylor also scored nine in the 2011 and 2013 games against Texas Tech.
Showing off the new steel gray helmets today. #SicTech pic.twitter.com/CJIFOwTj4L
— Baylor Football (@BUFootball) October 3, 2015 On Twitter:
 @tommycummings
